"@@ -10,11 +10,17 @@ author: justinha\n manager: dougeby\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n # Customer intent: As an identity administrator, I want to understand how to use security questions in Microsoft Entra ID to improve and secure user sign-in events.\n+# Uses details from securing Entra include file entra-docs-pr\\docs\\includes\\secure-recommendations\\22072.md for important box.\n ---\n # Authentication methods in Microsoft Entra ID - security questions\n \n Security questions aren't used as an authentication method during a sign-in event. Instead, security questions can be used during the self-service password reset (SSPR) process to confirm who you are. Administrator accounts can't use security questions as verification method with SSPR.\n \n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> Allowing security questions as a self-service password reset (SSPR) method weakens the password reset process because answers are frequently guessable, reused across sites, or discoverable through open-source intelligence (OSINT). Threat actors enumerate or phish users, derive likely responses (family names, schools, and locations), and then trigger password reset flows to bypass stronger methods by exploiting the weaker knowledge-based gate. After they successfully reset a password on an account that isn't protected by multifactor authentication they can: gain valid primary credentials, establish session tokens, and laterally expand by registering more durable authentication methods, add forwarding rules, or exfiltrate sensitive data.\n+> \n+> Eliminating this method removes a weak link in the password reset process. Some organizations might have specific business reasons for leaving security questions enabled, but this isn't recommended.\n+\n When users register for SSPR, they're prompted to choose the authentication methods to use. If they choose to use security questions, they pick from a set of questions to prompt for and then provide their own answers.\n \n ![Screenshot of the Microsoft Entra admin center that shows authentication methods and options for security questions](media/concept-authentication-methods/security-questions-authentication-method.png)" }, { "sha": "9b972d2aeb411450ac74b10be32ed66fbd9267f0", "filename": "docs/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 2, "deletions": 2, "changes": 4, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Fconcept-authentication-strength-advanced-options.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -15,12 +15,12 @@ ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n \n Administrators can also create up to 15 of their own custom authentication strengths to exactly suit their requirements. A custom authentication strength can contain any of the supported combinations in the preceding table. \n \n-1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as an Administrator.\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Security Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator).\n 1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Authentication methods** > **Authentication strengths**.\n 1. Select **New authentication strength**.\n 1. Provide a descriptive **Name** for your new authentication strength.\n 1. Optionally provide a **Description**.\n-1. Select any of the available methods you want to allow.\n+1. Select the available methods you want to allow, like those under Phishing-resistant MFA, Passwordless MFA, and Temporary Access Pass.\n 1. Choose **Next** and review the policy configuration.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" border=\"true\" source=\"media/concept-authentication-strengths/authentication-strength-custom.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot showing the creation of a custom authentication strength.\":::" }, { "sha": "55f38291b733f43f30bee85ec23395456f7f489f", "filename": "docs/identity/authentication/tutorial-enable-sspr.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 3, "changes": 4, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Ftutorial-enable-sspr.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Ftutorial-enable-sspr.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fauthentication%2Ftutorial-enable-sspr.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -74,15 +74,13 @@ When users need to unlock their account or reset their password, they're prompte\n \n To improve security, you can increase the number of authentication methods required for SSPR.\n \n-1. Global and Domain Local group scopes aren't supported for groups provisioned to AD DS. You need to check and update the group scope before you convert Group SOA for security groups that you want to provision back to AD DS.\n+If you plan to provision a converted SOA security group (not mail-enabled) back to AD DS, then you need to complete these steps to preserve the original organizational unit (OU) path:\n+\n+1. Convert the Source of Authority (SOA) when ready. \n+1. Use custom expressions to ensure Cloud Sync provisions groups back to AD DS with the same CN and OU values. \n+\n+For more information, see [Provision groups to Active Directory Domain Services by using Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync](cloud-sync/tutorial-group-provisioning.md).\n \n ### Transition group management\n \n-Microsoft Entra ID Governance supports governance of Microsoft Entra ID security groups and Microsoft 365 groups. While Distribution Lists (DLs) and Mail-Enabled Security Groups (MESGs) can exist in the cloud, they're Exchange concepts and you can't manage them in the Microsoft Entra admin center or with Microsoft Graph APIs.\n+Microsoft Entra ID Governance supports governance of Microsoft Entra ID security groups and Microsoft 365 groups. While Distribution Lists (DLs) and Mail-Enabled Security Groups (MESGs) can exist in the cloud, they're Exchange concepts and you can't manage them in the Microsoft Entra admin center or with Microsoft Graph APIs. So, if you don't need a group to remain mail-enabled, convert it to a standard security group in AD DS, sync the group, and then convert the SOA.\n \n You should replace DLs and MESGs with Microsoft 365 groups for collaboration and access management scenarios. Groups provisioned to AD DS using Cloud Sync can only contain on-premises synchronized users or other cloud-created security groups." }, { "sha": "72ded12d047ee2ef6dcaf1e398c85cd0bca49300", "filename": "docs/identity/hybrid/includes/prepare-converted-groups.md", "status": "added", "additions": 144, "deletions": 0, "changes": 144, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fincludes%2Fprepare-converted-groups.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fincludes%2Fprepare-converted-groups.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fincludes%2Fprepare-converted-groups.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,144 @@\n+---\n+title: Prepare SOA converted groups for provisioning to their original organizational unit (OU) path\n+description: Steps to prepare SOA converted groups for provisioning to their original organizational unit (OU) path\n+author: omondiatieno\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: Include\n+ms.date: 10/10/2025\n+ms.author: jomondi\n+ms.custom: Include file\n+---\n+## Prepare SOA converted groups for provisioning to their original organizational unit (OU) path\n+\n+Complete these steps to prepare groups that you plan to convert to be cloud-managed for provisioning from Microsoft Entra ID back to their original OU path in Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) on-premises:\n+\n+1. Change the AD DS group scope to Universal. \n+1. Create a special application.\n+1. Create the directory extension property for groups.\n+\n+### Change the group scope for the AD DS groups to Universal\n+\n+1. Open Active Directory Administrative Center.\n+1. Right-click a group, click **Properties**.\n+1. In the **Group** section, select **Universal** as the group scope.\n+1. Click **Save**.\n+\n+### Create the extension \n+\n+Cloud Sync only supports extensions created on a special application called *CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp*. If the app doesn't exist in your tenant, you must create it. This step is performed once per tenant. \n+\n+For more information about how to create the extension, see [Cloud sync directory extensions and custom attribute mapping](/entra/identity/hybrid/cloud-sync/custom-attribute-mapping).\n+ \n+#### [**Graph PowerShell**](#tab/ps)\n+\n+1. Open an elevated PowerShell window and run the following commands to install modules and connect: \n+\n+ ```powershell\n+ Install-Module Microsoft.Graph -Scope CurrentUser -Force \n+ Connect-MgGraph -Scopes \"Application.ReadWrite.All\",\"Directory.ReadWrite.All\",\"Directory.AccessAsUser.All\" \n+ ```\n+\n+1. Check if the application exists. If it doesn't, create it. Also ensure a service principal is present. \n+\n+ ```powershell\n+ $tenantId = (Get-MgOrganization).Id \n+ $app = Get-MgApplication -Filter \"identifierUris/any(uri:uri eq 'API://$tenantId/CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp')\" \n+ if (-not $app) { \n+ $app = New-MgApplication -DisplayName \"CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp\" -IdentifierUris \"API://$tenantId/CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp\" \n+ } \n+ \n+ $sp = Get-MgServicePrincipal -Filter \"AppId eq '$($app.AppId)'\" \n+ if (-not $sp) { \n+ $sp = New-MgServicePrincipal -AppId $app.AppId \n+ } \n+ ```\n+\n+1. Now add a directory extension property named *GroupDN*. This will be a string attribute available on group objects. \n+\n+ ```powershell\n+ New-MgApplicationExtensionProperty ` \n+ -ApplicationId $app.Id ` \n+ -Name \"GroupDN\" ` \n+ -DataType \"String\" ` \n+ -TargetObjects Group \n+ ```\n+ \n+For more information about how to create the directory extension property for groups, see [Cloud sync directory extensions and custom attribute mapping](/entra/identity/hybrid/cloud-sync/custom-attribute-mapping).\n+\n+#### [**Graph Explorer**](#tab/ge)\n+ \n+1. Check if application with the identifier URI `API:///CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp` exists.\n+\n+ ```https\n+ GET /applications?$filter=identifierUris/any(uri:uri eq 'api:///CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp')\n+ ```\n+\n+ For more information, see [Get application](/graph/api/application-get?view=graph-rest-1.0&tabs=http&preserve-view=true)\n+ \n+1. If the application doesn't exist, create the application with identifier URI `API:///CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp`:\n+\n+ ```https\n+ POST https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/applications\n+ Content-type: application/json\n+\n+ {\n+ \"displayName\": \"CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp\",\n+ \"identifierUris\": [\"api:///CloudSyncCustomExtensionsApp\"]\n+ }\n+ ```\n+ \n+ For more information, see [create application](/graph/api/application-post-applications?view=graph-rest-1.0&tabs=http&preserve-view=true).\n+\n+1. Create a directory extension in Microsoft Entra ID. For example, a new extension called 'GroupDN', of string type, for Group objects:\n+\n+ ```https\n+ POST https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/applications//extensionProperties\n+ Content-type: application/json\n+ \n+ {\n+ \"name\": \"GroupDN\",\n+ \"dataType\": \"String\",\n+ \"isMultiValued\": false,\n+ \"targetObjects\": [\n+ \"Group\"\n+ ]\n+ } \n+ ```\n+\n+### Configure Cloud Sync attribute mapping\n+\n+Next, tell Cloud Sync to populate this extension property with the groupâ€™s Distinguished Name (DN) from Active Directory. This step ensures the original OU and CN information are preserved in Microsoft Entra ID.\n+\n+1. Open Microsoft Entra admin center > **Entra ID** > **Entra Connect** > **Cloud Sync**.\n+2. Select your AD-to-Microsoft Entra ID configuration.\n+3. Go to **Attribute mappings**.\n+4. At the top, switch **Object type** to **Group**.\n+5. Add a new attribute mapping.\n+ - Mapping type: Direct\n+ - Source attribute: distinguishedName (the on-premises groupâ€™s DN)\n+ - Target attribute: `extension__GroupDN`\n+6. Save the schema to trigger a sync.\n+\n+By mapping distinguishedName directly, you capture the groupâ€™s full DN (CN + OU path) in the extension property, making it easier to later reconstruct both CN and OU when provisioning back to AD.\n+\n+### Verify that the mapping worked\n+\n+Once sync runs, you should verify that the extension property is populated with the DN. Use Microsoft Graph PowerShell:\n+\n+```powershell\n+$clientId = $app.AppId\n+$propName = \"extension_{0}_GroupDN\" -f ($clientId -replace \"-\",\"\")\n+$grp = Get-MgGroup -Filter \"displayName eq 'My Security Group'\" -ConsistencyLevel eventual\n+Get-MgGroup -GroupId $grp.Id -Property \"id,displayName,$propName\" |\n+ Select-Object id, displayName, @{n=$propName; e={$_.\"$propName\"}}\n+```\n+\n+This command returns the group with its DN stored in the extension property. You can also test using Graph Explorer by querying:\n+\n+```https\n+GET /v1.0/groups/{id}?$select=displayName,extension__GroupDN\n+```\n+\n+### Convert Source of Authority (SOA)\n+\n+Once you have validated the DN is stored in the extension, you can convert the groupâ€™s Source of Authority to Microsoft Entra ID. This change makes the group cloud-managed while preserving its original DN in the extension for later use in group provisioning to AD DS." }, { "sha": "d42a16cf86c9cf19ec4a424ab9976009521160fe", "filename": "docs/identity/saas-apps/britive-provisioning-tutorial.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 9, "deletions": 9, "changes": 18, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fbritive-provisioning-tutorial.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fbritive-provisioning-tutorial.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fsaas-apps%2Fbritive-provisioning-tutorial.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -43,26 +43,26 @@ The scenario outlined in this article assumes that you already have the followin\n \n ## Step 2: Configure Britive to support provisioning with Microsoft Entra ID\n \n-The application has to be manually configured using the steps provided in the this section:\n-1. @@\n+---\n+title: Enforce standards for app secrets and certificates\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Application management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Without proper application management policies, threat actors can exploit weak or misconfigured application credentials to get unauthorized access to organizational resources. Applications using long-lived password secrets or certificates create extended attack windows where compromised credentials stay valid for extended periods. If an application uses client secrets that are hardcoded in configuration files or have weak password requirements, threat actors can extract these credentials through different means, including source code repositories, configuration dumps, or memory analysis. If threat actors get these credentials, they can perform lateral movement within the environment, escalate privileges if the application has elevated permissions, establish persistence by creating more backdoor credentials, modify application configuration, or exfiltrate data. The lack of credential lifecycle management lets compromised credentials remain active indefinitely, giving threat actors sustained access to organizational assets and the ability to conduct data exfiltration, system manipulation, or deploy more malicious tools without detection. \n+\n+Configuring appropriate app management policies helps organizations stay ahead of these threats.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Learn how to enforce secret and certificate standards using application management policies](/entra/identity/enterprise-apps/tutorial-enforce-secret-standards)" }, { "sha": "5f81fe520dd7634943162a8ecf6f2d0a7fbf1f70", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21802.md", @@\n+---\n+title: Protected actions are enabled for high-impact management tasks\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 09/23/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n+# category: Privileged access\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Threat actors who gain privileged access to a tenant can manipulate identity, access, and security configurations. This type of attack can result in environment-wide compromise and loss of control over organizational assets. Take action to protect high-impact management tasks associated with Conditional Access policies, cross-tenant access settings, hard deletions, and network locations that are critical to maintaining security.\n+\n+Protected actions let administrators secure these tasks with extra security controls, such as stronger authentication methods (passwordless MFA or phishing-resistant MFA), the use of Privileged Access Workstation (PAW) devices, or shorter session timeouts.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Add, test, or remove protected actions in Microsoft Entra ID](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/protected-actions-add)" }, { "sha": "8b1db6269bd4dd3b3ed8c0f86670afab39360eb4", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21835.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 2, "deletions": 2, "changes": 4, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21835.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21835.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21835.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -4,7 +4,7 @@ ms.author: joflore\n author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 08/26/2025\n+ms.date: 09/26/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation, sfi-ga-nochange\n # sfipillar: Protect engineering systems\n # category: Application management\n@@ -17,4 +17,4 @@ Microsoft recommends that organizations have two cloud-only emergency access acc\n \n **Remediation action**\n \n-Create accounts following the [emergency access account recommendations](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access).\n+- Create accounts following the [emergency access account recommendations](/entra/identity/role-based-access-control/security-emergency-access)." }, { "sha": "9174c8e7e5ff6534f5f744e5584908bcc7d87e23", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21837.md", "status": "added", "additions": 19, "deletions": 0, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21837.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21837.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21837.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@\n+---\n+title: Limit the maximum number of devices per user to 10\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 09/26/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect engineering systems\n+# category: Devices\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Controlling device proliferation is important. Set a reasonable limit on the number of devices each user can register in your Microsoft Entra ID tenant. Limiting device registration maintains security while allowing business flexibility. Microsoft Entra ID lets users register up to 50 devices by default. Reducing this number to 10 minimizes the attack surface and simplifies device management.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- Learn how to [limit the maximum number of devices per user](/entra/identity/devices/manage-device-identities#configure-device-settings)." }, { "sha": "ce66d8a66355c7d79b2264f19b1ee66dae8e6119", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21839.md", "status": "added", "additions": 22, "deletions": 0, "changes": 22, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21839.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@\n+---\n+title: Passkey authentication method enabled\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/10/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+When passkey authentication isn't enabled in Microsoft Entra ID, organizations rely on password-based authentication methods that are vulnerable to phishing, credential theft, and replay attacks. Attackers can use stolen passwords to gain initial access, bypass traditional multifactor authentication through Adversary-in-the-Middle (AiTM) attacks, and establish persistent access through token theft.\n+\n+Passkeys provide phishing-resistant authentication using cryptographic proof that attackers can't phish, intercept, or replay. Enabling passkeys eliminates the foundational vulnerability that enables credential-based attack chains.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- Learn how to [enable the passkey authentication method](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2#enable-passkey-fido2-authentication-method).\n+- Learn how to [plan a phishing-resistant passwordless authentication deployment](/entra/identity/authentication/how-to-plan-prerequisites-phishing-resistant-passwordless-authentication)." }, { "sha": "6a49b007bfd4346e909609bd0ea79c28d364f3ba", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21841.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21841.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Microsoft Authenticator app report suspicious activity setting is enabled\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Threat actors increasingly rely on prompt bombing and real-time phishing proxies to coerce or trick users into approving fraudulent multifactor authentication (MFA) challenges. Without the Microsoft Authenticator app's **Report suspicious activity** capability enabled, an attacker can iterate until a fatigued user accepts. This type of attack can lead to privilege escalation, persistence, lateral movement into sensitive workloads, data exfiltration, or destructive actions.\n+\n+When reporting is enabled for all users, any unexpected push or phone prompt can be actively flagged, immediately elevating the user to high user risk and generating a high-fidelity user risk detection (userReportedSuspiciousActivity) that risk-based Conditional Access policies or other response automation can use to block or require secure remediation. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Enable the report suspicious activity setting in the Microsoft Authenticator app](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-mfa-mfasettings#report-suspicious-activity)" }, { "sha": "ffee476a9c64b202a52962b147b14c00b7567cf8", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21845.md", "status": "added", "additions": 24, "deletions": 0, "changes": 24, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21845.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@\n+---\n+title: Temporary access pass is enabled\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Without Temporary Access Pass (TAP) enabled, organizations face significant challenges in securely bootstrapping user credentials, creating a vulnerability where users rely on weaker authentication mechanisms during their initial setup. When users cannot register phishing-resistant credentials like FIDO2 security keys or Windows Hello for Business due to lack of existing strong authentication methods, they remain exposed to credential-based attacks including phishing, password spray, or similar attacks. Threat actors can exploit this registration gap by targeting users during their most vulnerable state, when they have limited authentication options available and must rely on traditional username + password combinations. This exposure enables threat actors to compromise user accounts during the critical bootstrapping phase, allowing them to intercept or manipulate the registration process for stronger authentication methods, ultimately gaining persistent access to organizational resources and potentially escalating privileges before security controls are fully established. \n+\n+Enable TAP and use it with security info registration to secure this potential gap in your defenses.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Learn how to enable Temporary Access Pass in the Authentication methods policy](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-authentication-temporary-access-pass#enable-the-temporary-access-pass-policy)\n+- [Learn how to update authentication strength policies to include Temporary Access Pass](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-strength-advanced-options)\n+- [Learn how to create a Conditional Access policy for security info registration with authentication strength enforcement](/entra/identity/conditional-access/policy-all-users-security-info-registration)\n+ \n\\ No newline at end of file" }, { "sha": "c190dc68457835102ec62c4472322b44eea50b6f", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21848.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21848.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Add organizational terms to the banned password list\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/09/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+Organizations that don't populate and enforce the custom banned password list expose themselves to a systematic attack chain where threat actors exploit predictable organizational password patterns. These threat actors typically start with reconnaissance phases, where they gather open-source intelligence (OSINT) from websites, social media, and public records to identify likely password components. With this knowledge, they launch password spray attacks that test organization-specific password variations across multiple user accounts, staying under lockout thresholds to avoid detection. Without the protection the custom banned password list offers, employees often add familiar organizational terms to their passwords, like locations, product names, and industry terms, creating consistent attack vectors. \n+\n+The custom banned password list helps organizations plug this critical gap to prevent easily guessed passwords that could lead to initial access and subsequent lateral movement within the environment.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Learn how to enable custom banned password protection and add organizational terms](/entra/identity/authentication/tutorial-configure-custom-password-protection)" }, { "sha": "f217e5f134c530a87c289ddb23388281575f4b63", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21850.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21850.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Smart lockout threshold set to 10 or less\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Low\n+---\n+When the smart lockout threshold is set to more than 10, threat actors can exploit the configuration to conduct reconnaissance, identify valid user accounts without triggering lockout protections, and establish initial access without detection. Once attackers gain initial access, they can move laterally through the environment by using the compromised account to access resources and escalate privileges.\n+\n+Smart lockout helps lock out bad actors who try to guess your users' passwords or use brute force methods to get in. Smart lockout recognizes sign-ins that come from valid users and treats them differently than ones of attackers and other unknown sources. A threshold of more than 10 provides insufficient protection against automated password spray attacks, making it easier for threat actors to compromise accounts while evading detection mechanisms. \n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Set Microsoft Entra smart lockout threshold to 10 or less](/entra/identity/authentication/howto-password-smart-lockout)." }, { "sha": "bce63f3f72f7dac91a56a74f9b5027dd3952a332", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21874.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 9, "deletions": 10, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21874.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21874.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21874.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -1,22 +1,21 @@\n ---\n-title: Allow/Deny lists of domains to restrict external collaboration are configured\n-ms.author: sarahlipsey\n-author: shlipsey3\n+title: Guest access is limited to approved tenants\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.topic: include\n-ms.date: 07/07/2025\n+ms.date: 10/10/2025\n ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n # sfipillar: Protect tenants and isolate production systems\n # category: External collaboration\n # risklevel: Medium\n # userimpact: Medium\n-# implementationcost: Medium\n+# implementationcost: High\n ---\n-Without configured domain allow/deny lists for external collaboration, organizations lack essential domain-level access controls that act as the frontline defense in their security model. Domain allow/deny lists operate at the tenant level and take precedence over Cross-Tenant Access Policies (XTAP), blocking invitations from domains on the deny list regardless of cross-tenant access settings. While XTAP enables granular controls for specific trusted tenants, domain restrictions are critical for preventing invitations from unknown or unverified domains that haven't been explicitly allowed.\n+Limiting guest access to a known and approved list of tenants helps to prevent threat actors from exploiting unrestricted guest access to establish initial access through compromised external accounts or by creating accounts in untrusted tenants. Threat actors who gain access through an unrestricted domain can discover internal resources, users, and applications to perform additional attacks. \n \n-Without these restrictions, internal users can invite external accounts from any domainâ€”including potentially compromised or attacker-controlled domains. Threat actors can register domains that appear legitimate to conduct social engineering attacks, tricking users into sending collaboration invitations that circumvent XTAP's targeted protections. Once granted access, these external guest accounts can be used for reconnaissance, mapping internal resources, user relationships, and collaboration patterns.\n-\n-These invited accounts provide persistent access that appears legitimate in audit logs and security monitoring systems. Attackers can maintain a long-term presence to collect data, access shared resources, documents, and applications configured for external collaboration, and potentially exfiltrate data through authorized channels without triggering alerts.\n+Organizations should take inventory and configure an allowlist or blocklist to control B2B collaboration invitations from specific organizations. Without these controls, threat actors might use social engineering techniques to obtain invitations from legitimate internal users. \n \n **Remediation action**\n-- [Configure domain-based allow or deny lists](../../external-id/allow-deny-list.md#set-the-allow-or-blocklist-policy-in-the-portal)\n\\ No newline at end of file\n+\n+- Learn how to [set up a list of approved domains](/entra/external-id/allow-deny-list#add-an-allowlist)." }, { "sha": "f834ee099f23e3c340b30b38b9f551fcee05f02d", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21893.md", "status": "added", "additions": 19, "deletions": 0, "changes": 19, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21893.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21893.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21893.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@\n+---\n+title: All users are required to register for MFA\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Access control\n+# risklevel: Low\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Require multifactor authentication (MFA) registration for all users. Based on studies, your account is more than 99% less likely to be compromised if you're using MFA. Even if you don't require MFA all the time, this policy ensures your users are ready when it's needed.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure the multifactor authentication registration policy](/entra/id-protection/howto-identity-protection-configure-mfa-policy)" }, { "sha": "29528d01d740db1bdb9d7d91f1201fa08484d446", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/21953.md", "status": "added", "additions": 21, "deletions": 0, "changes": 21, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F21953.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,21 @@\n+---\n+title: Local Admin Password Solution is deployed\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Devices\n+# risklevel: High\n+# userimpact: Low\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Without Local Admin Password Solution (LAPS) deployed, threat actors exploit static local administrator passwords to establish initial access. After threat actors compromise a single device with a shared local administrator credential, they can move laterally across the environment and authenticate to other systems sharing the same password. Compromised local administrator access gives threat actors system-level privileges, letting them disable security controls, install persistent backdoors, exfiltrate sensitive data, and establish command and control channels. \n+\n+The automated password rotation and centralized management of LAPS closes this security gap and adds controls to help manage who has access to these critical accounts. Without solutions like LAPS, you can't detect or respond to unauthorized use of local administrator accounts, giving threat actors extended dwell time to achieve their objectives while remaining undetected.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Configure Windows Local Administrator Password Solution](/entra/identity/devices/howto-manage-local-admin-passwords)." }, { "sha": "30890702ed0fffdb212b6d60439bacc0ff6518d2", "filename": "docs/includes/secure-recommendations/22072.md", "status": "added", "additions": 22, "deletions": 0, "changes": 22, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F22072.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F22072.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fincludes%2Fsecure-recommendations%2F22072.md?ref=0318bf778963f6e5fe5770726eeac88ef3d9213b", "patch": "@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@\n+---\n+title: Self-service password reset doesn't use security questions\n+ms.author: joflore\n+author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n+ms.service: entra-id\n+ms.topic: include\n+ms.date: 10/07/2025\n+ms.custom: Identity-Secure-Recommendation\n+# sfipillar: Protect identities and secrets\n+# category: Credential management\n+# risklevel: Medium\n+# userimpact: Medium\n+# implementationcost: Medium\n+---\n+Allowing security questions as a self-service password reset (SSPR) method weakens the password reset process because answers are frequently guessable, reused across sites, or discoverable through open-source intelligence (OSINT). Threat actors enumerate or phish users, derive likely responses (family names, schools, and locations), and then trigger password reset flows to bypass stronger methods by exploiting the weaker knowledge-based gate. After they successfully reset a password on an account that isn't protected by multifactor authentication they can: gain valid primary credentials, establish session tokens, and laterally expand by registering more durable authentication methods, add forwarding rules, or exfiltrate sensitive data.\n+\n+Eliminating this method removes a weak link in the password reset process. Some organizations might have specific business reasons for leaving security questions enabled, but this isn't recommended.\n+\n+**Remediation action**\n+\n+- [Disable security questions in SSPR policy](/entra/identity/authentication/concept-authentication-security-questions)\n+- [Select authentication methods and registration options](/entra/identity/authentication/tutorial-enable-sspr#select-authentication-methods-and-registration-options)" } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary.","role":"user"}
ai_summary.Response: This commit updates several Microsoft Entra ID documentation pages, introducing new security recommendations and refining existing ones. Key changes include adding recommendations for passkey authentication, enforcing app secret standards, and limiting device registrations. The commit also enhances guidance on provisioning groups to Active Directory Domain Services by preserving original OU paths and updates tutorials for Britive SSO and provisioning. Additionally, it improves the bulk download functionality for groups and group members, making it more user-friendly.

ai_summary.Response: These commits refine the documentation for integrating Britive with Microsoft Entra ID. The changes primarily involve updating instructions for configuring Britive to support provisioning and single sign-on (SSO). Minor edits include correcting grammatical errors and ensuring consistent phrasing, such as changing "followin" to "following" and "Re-Create" to "Recreate token" for better clarity. Additionally, a few image files were updated, although the specific changes to these images are not detailed in the commit diffs.
